content.description:
Start at the crescent shaped hold as for

Where Boneheads Dare

.   Once standing on this hold move up and right on small edges.

Continue up the blunt arete to the top of the boulder.

climbs.name: Problem B AKA Boneheads Slab Right

content.description:
This climbs a line of good pockets and features up the slab.

Start with a long reach up to a large pocket, and follow the good pockets directly up the slab.

This also acts as a good descent from the other problems on the boulder.
content.location: Right side of the south face.

content.description:
A committing problem, Where Boneheads Dare entices many who come to Boulder Basin.

Start on the crescent shaped crimper and move up to the tiny crimp higher up.  Once the feet are established in the starting hold, move up and slightly left to top out.

The physical / technical crux is down low.  Although the remaining moves are physically easier, it's not for the faint of heart.
content.location:
One of the easiest problems to find, Where Boneheads Dare is on the boulder closest to the campground loop road (and facing it) between sites 21 and 20.

The most popular way to get off is to jump across a 4' span to a lower boulder north of the Where Boneheads Dare boulder is.  Another option is to downclimb a V0 / V1 hueco problem on the east side of the boulder.

content.description: Traverse across the Fallen Arch rock on the huecos

One of So Cal's most beautiful boulder problems, the Fallen Arch climbs the prominent right-leaning corner just behind Where Boneheads Dare.  The reason for its name is obvious, when you see the huge flake laying there at the base.  It adds a bit of spook factor, although it's not really in the landing zone.

The rock to the left of the dihedral is black and the right side is white, making the climb look sort of like a yin-yang symbol.  The idea of uniting opposing forces is apropos... Layback easily up till you can reach an obvious sloping dish on the lip, make a powerful and committing mantle, then delicately (desperately) get stood up on the dish and crank thin slab moves to the top.
content.location: On the south side of the boulder immediately behind (touching) Where Boneheads Dare.

content.description:
This great problem climbs a series of fingery edges up a steep smooth face to an obvious jug midway and then easier moves to a high topout.

Tricky footwork down low and a big reach/throw to a hold before the jug midway makes this a little harder than appearances might suggest on this very "gym-like" boulder problem.
content.location: West face of the boulder and just left of a large pine tree between Smackdown and Kayla.

content.description: just to the right of Where Boneheads Dare is a flake with a good undercling on the right side and a grainy sidepull on the left side. Use this flake and some feet to do a remarkably comp-style move to a sloping hueco. After that, it's foot magic and body tension to gain the higher juggy hueco that usually has pine needles in it. it's all over once you hit that hueco.
content.location: just to the right of where boneheads dare
